fields.description:
We have these configuration settings in wrapper.conf for Bamboo.

{code}
# Initial Java Heap Size (in MB)
wrapper.java.initmemory=512

# Maximum Java Heap Size (in MB)
wrapper.java.maxmemory=1024

......

wrapper.java.additional.3=-Xms512m
wrapper.java.additional.4=-Xmx1024m
{code}

Shouldn't we get rid of one of the pairs?
fields.summary: Duplicate configuration settings in wrapper.conf

fields.description:
When a user sets up a Bitbucket repository in Bamboo, and Bamboo needs to access the web through a proxy and therefore has been setup with system properties -Dhttp.proxyHost and -Dhttp.proxyPort, these properties are not respected when talking to Bitbucket during repo setup, editing and validation.

The same issue likely exists when using the GitHub Bamboo repository.
fields.summary: Bitbucket and possibly GitHub repository validation doesn't respect http proxyhosts java system properties

fields.description: When on the dashboard you see little spinning icons representing the status of a build - but when clicking on that spinner you're actually taken to the plan overview page. The spinner represents the actual build "object" - clicking it feels like you should go to the page showing the full progress and logs.
fields.summary: Spinning status icon link doesn't take you to the expected location
Make ChangeDetectionManager available to plugins 2

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As a build administrator I want to change the Bamboo build number to another number to preserve continuity of build numbers when migrating from other continuous integration systems.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a form field in build administration where the build number can be changed.
 
h3. Workarounds

The build number can be reset by cloning the existing plan to create a replacement.  The build number can be _*increased*_ using a SQL query.  The build number cannot be _decreased_ due to conflicts with multiple tables that reference the past builds.

For complete details of the workarounds please see [Unable to change the current build number in Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Unable+to+change+the+current+build+number+in+Bamboo]
fields.summary: Ability to modify the current build number, bambooBuildNumber

fields.description:
Currently it is possible to *use* a variable value, but not to *change* it while a task is running.

This would be useful to allow one Task/Stage to store a value in the server so that other Task/Stage can have access to it.
h3. Atlassian answer
{quote}Modifying global and plan variables will not be implemented due to concurrency issues that would be created.

However, since Bamboo 5.7 you can use Inject Variables task to add variables to "result" scope and use them later on, in subsequent Task, Stages and to create deployment release.
{quote}
fields.summary: Allow Tasks to change Global and Plan variables

fields.description:
It seems like the enable is cached or otherwise not available to the queue processing. I can only reproduce this with automation. It seems delaying for a few seconds is sufficient to make it work.
# disable a plan
# enable a plan
# queue a build - this will fail if run too quickly after the enable

fields.description:
We've got a highly used Bamboo instance where we're hitting our 100 remote agent limit.
We have plans to obtain further licenses, but we'd also like the ability to have the builds in the queue be automatically prioritized so some of the less-important plans/jobs can be pushed down the queue if a more important build/job is added to queue.

If two builds with the same priority are added to the queue, then it's first-come-first-served.

Priority could be defined on a pretty basic scale of:
"High","Medium","Low", with all builds being defined as "Medium" by default.
fields.summary: Allow a priority to be set on build plans, to allow for automatic build queue placement

fields.description:
I am often in a tight commit/see CI/try to fix loop to fix test problems that occur only on CI build.
The default 180s repository delay is too long for me in this case - I want the plan to trigger NOW (but not until the new commit hits the repository)

Currently I change the interval to 30s, but if I forget to reset it back the polling stays too often afterwards.

If I had "check now" button I could hammer it until I got the build instead of tweaking the config.

fields.description:
One of our users has been complaining about the length of time it takes to load the My Bamboo tab on the dashboard since we moved from 3.1.4 - > 3.3.2.
This particular user is reporting a 40+ second load time for that tab.
I know there was a significant rework of the My Bamboo tab for 3.3, so I suspect it's related.

The issue appears to be that Bamboo tries to display far too much information in the latest changes section. I think performance would be improved if that section behaved more like an activity stream with a "More" button after X number of entries.

SUMMARY
Bamboo reports Build Failed but logs indicate BUILD SUCCESS (and the possible culprits listed in help documentation are not present)

I have read the following documentation: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+indicates+that+my+Ant+or+Maven+builds+failed%2C+even+though+they+were+successful?showComments=true&showCommentArea=true#addcomment

However, nothing listed in that documentation applies to build I am noticing this in:

1. The logs show "BUILD SUCCESS"
2. The builds return with a code 0
fields.summary: Bamboo reports Build Failed but logs indicate BUILD SUCCESS (and the possible culprits listed in help documentation are not present)

fields.description:
Mercurial does not respect the "-Dhttp.proxyPort" property that is passed to Bamboo server or agent, as we are forking the actual hg native binary. It runs in a separate process and it is not written in Java.

The right way to configure hg to use a proxy is to set the http_proxy.host, and potentially http_proxy.user and http_proxy.password environment variables:
http://www.markhneedham.com/blog/2009/05/13/mercurial-pulling-from-behind-a-proxy/

For https there is also a https_proxy as environment variable.

We should document what should be done to access Mercurial via a proxy.

If using the Bitbucket repository in Bamboo to connect to Bitbucket (rather a simple Mercurial repository, which could also be used to connect to Bitbucket) one also needs to set the -Dhttp.proxyHost and -Dhttp.proxyPort parameters of Bamboo server. Thsi will work once BAM-10287 is fixed.

This needs to be mentioned, and linked to a more generic doc which I hope we already have about how to make Bamboo access the web through a proxy.

We also need to do some research and document how to get Git and GitHub repository to work over a proxy.
fields.summary: Document how to connect to a Mercurial, Git, Bitbucket or Github source repositories via a http or https proxy

fields.description:
We have a set of .NET code that relies on projects being siblings in a directory structure in order for dependencies to operate properly.  Example:

* project1/MyAssembly
* project2/MyOtherAssembly

These projects would ideally build separately since they are being managed in different SCM repositories and have different life cycles.  Since Bamboo does not support specifying an absolute path for the build workspace (both Jenkins and TeamCity do), the only option (without modifying the source/build scripts) is to bundle the jobs for these different assemblies into the same project/stage. This is not optimal.

Bamboo should allow for the workspace path to be specified as an absolute path to enable situations like this.
fields.summary: Allow specification of absolute paths for the build workspace

fields.description:
from [here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/20476/bamboo-support-for-findbugs-no-support-for-multimodule-builds]
----
I'm putting this review of the Bamboo Findbugs plugin here because the plugins.atlassian.com review function is broken. I'd like to get some feedback about whether there are any plans to improve the plugin:

I'm using version 2.7 of the Bamboo Findbugs plugin on version 3.2.2 build 2718 of Bamboo.

The findbugs report is hidden away on the Job page rather than at front-of-house like it is on Jenkins CI. It's also linked to the overall Job rather than the particular run of a Job (e.g. execution #8). That makes some sense as I guess the plugin is serving up the current state of the build directory. Luckily, I don't choose to clear down my build directory *after* builds. I haven't tested, but I'm not too confident that the plugin will work with multiple remote agents.

*The showstopper for me is that it doesn't support multimodule builds. I have the Miscellaneous --> Findbugs configuration set to look in **/target and the findbugs plugin adds the tab into the Job results. Unfortunately it displays nothing but an empty graph.*

*Also, warning message when displaying the plugin page:*

*This page seems to be using a legacy way of displaying the tabs. Please contact the plugin developer. The page should be fixed to specify a specific decorator ('plan') please visit the plugin upgrade guide for details.*

I'm surprised to see this bearing in mind the plugin is maintained by Atlassian Labs.

----

https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FNDBUG-1 - this bug is closed, indicating that multimodule builds should be supported.
fields.summary: Update Bamboo Findbugs plugin and add support for multimodule in it

1. Install fresh Bamboo and login to Bamboo instance
2. Click create plan "Create a New Plan" and fill in all fields (do not click button)
3. Wait until session expires
4. If session expires click "Configure Tasks"
5. Now login screen is shown
6. Log in
7. Now "Create a New Plan" screen is shown once again but with empty fields.
8. It would be cool if after successful login for has the same values

fields.description:
We shouldn't generate empty artifact links when there are no artifacts for the build
Bamboo shows an artifact link; clicking on that link takes to a page that shows the artifact's name.


h6. Steps to reproduce
Configure a  plan with a script (that just prints something and creates a directory "target"). 
Then, add an artifact (shared or not) something like: location = target, pattern = **/*.zip.

{code}

fields.description:
It seems like there is actually missing steps in the following documentation:
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Granting+Global+Permissions+to+Users+or+Groups#GrantingGlobalPermissionstoUsersorGroups-RevokingGlobalPermissions

after steps 3 it should ask the user to click on the *Edit Global Permissions* option. Overall it should look like the following:
# Click Dashboard and then Administration in the top navigation bar.
# Click Global Permissions in the left navigation column to display the 'Global Permissions' screen.
# Click on *Edit Global Permissions* to edit permission
# Locate the relevant user/group/all logged-in users/anonymous users.
# Deselect the check box for each permission that you wish to revoke from the user/group/all users/anonymous users.
# Click Save.
fields.summary: Update dopcumentation on the global permission

fields.description:
The trigger reason is not set correctly when continuing a build from JIRA.

It is set correctly to "Release build for <Version Name> by <Username>" when kicking off a new build from JIRA.

However, when continuing an existing build from JIRA, the trigger reason is set to "This build was manually triggered from the stage <Stage Name> by <Username>.

So the fact that it is a release build triggered from JIRA is lost.

See BAMJ-78 for more details and the use case.
fields.summary: When continuing a build from JIRA the trigger reason does not capture that it was triggered from JIRA

fields.description:
When JUnit tests are inside nested static public classes (perfectly legitimate), the output XMLs are not parsed correctly. So, for the following input:
{noformat}
  <testcase time="0.001" classname="com.carrotsearch.bugsinjira.SuiteAggregatorTest$Test1" name="method1"/>
  <testcase time="0" classname="com.carrotsearch.bugsinjira.SuiteAggregatorTest$Test2" name="method1"/>
{noformat}

Bamboo shows only 1 test case on SuiteAggregatorTest named "method1". Code to demonstrate the bug at github:
https://github.com/dweiss/jira-bugs

Screenshot from an example execution attached.
fields.summary: The count and list of tests parsed from XML files is incorrect if nested classes are used as test base.

Bamboo runs out of memory rendering the page that shows commits related to a build when there are lots of commits (> 500 or so).

Perhaps this page could show the commits in batches with controls to navigate through the batches.

I suspect the same happens with the page that shows issues related to a build when there are lots of issues.
